title: Friday, 2nd August 2019
bodyHTML:
11:08 am

Good morning. What have you learned today?

nightingale20201 morning all

I've learned that the German word for tailspin is "talfahrt".

PBateman morning

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Donald Trump’s wave of new tariffs against China triggered a steep sell-off in stocks and a rush of haven buying of government bonds on Friday as fears deepened about the threat posed by the trade dispute to global growth.

The worries led to the biggest two-day rally for US Treasuries since last May, pushing the benchmark 10-year yield down by 18 basis points over two sessions.

PBateman elsewhere, Trumponomics
Soundbuy Lumpi ist mein hunt
BE11:11am

(@nightingale20201: 100% of f all is still f all.)

BE11:13am

Let's head into Raymond James's very good Washington Policy briefing for the ticklist.

Greedy_When_Others_Are_Fearful hows the bond roadshow going/gone for sirius?
Soundbuy Two yrs of German and that's all I can say
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Why this happened. China has not started the agriculture purchases President Trump believes were promised during the June G20 meeting in
Japan. We have consistently heard that there has been considerable confusion on this commitment and the Chinese delegation does not believe that they made a firm commitment. In what was viewed as a sign of good faith, China sent signals 2 weeks ago that agriculture purchase were set to begin, giving way to this week’s meeting. However, little was accomplished at the meeting and there are no reports of any Chinese purchases of U.S. agriculture. Underreported, but arguably as, if not more important, is President Trump's focus on the flow of fentanyl from China to the
U.S. In his tweet, the President Trump wrote “my friend President Xi said that he would stop the sale of fentanyl to the United States – this never
happened, and many Americans continue to die!” We believe that President Trump and hardliners in his administration blame Chinese leadership for the flow of fentanyl from China to the U.S., and the associated deaths – a modern day Opium War.

BE11:14am

How will China respond? China does not want to be seen as caving to pressure from the Trump administration by beginning the purchase
of agricultural goods, according to our conversations with our trade contacts. There is a sense that these tariffs will occur regardless of their
purchases, so caving would achieve little. There is some expectation that this could reestablish some commitments to restart negotiations, but
that is far from certain. Chinese leaders are set to begin their annual Beidaihe leadership conference. There is an expectation that this year’s
conference will focus on the path forward in the U.S.-China trade war, unrest in Hong Kong, and relations with Taiwan. It appears likely that any
Chinese response may wait until later this month following these meetings, pushing up against the deadline and making the implementation of the tariffs more likely.

BE11:14am

Can the tariffs be avoided? With the caveat that Trump can be unpredictable ...

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Omg smile

BE11:14am

.... we believe the base case remains the implementation of the tariffs
on or around 9/1. The President could decide to impose tariffs on good that are “on the water” as of 9/1, delaying the actual implementation to
later in September, giving him more time to get China back to the negotiating table. For tariffs to be delayed, we would likely need a significant
purchase of U.S. agricultural goods, a commitment to purchase more into the future, and a Trump-Xi phone call that agrees to restart the trade
talks. Any restart would require a hard deadline, with the threat of escalating tariffs should a deal not be reached – essentially restarting the
process from December-May.

BE11:14am

So ........ currency war?

11:14 am
BE11:15am

We believe that threats to weaken the U.S. dollar are likely the next phase
in these trade wars. We have seen concerns that China will weaken the yuan to offset the impact of these tariffs. With other central banks likely to
ease more than the Fed, we see President Trump seeking to take executive action on exchange rates.

cracklenpop @SoundbuySchade...
BE11:15am

And with relation to the grown ups in the Fed?

BE11:15am

Market impact. If Trump really wanted his 50 bp cut, he should have tweeted yesterday. The return of these increased tariffs is clearly unwelcome news, especially for consumer staples and tech companies that had hoped they avoided these additional tariffs. Market sentiment, based upon
extensive conversations and meetings with clients, is that Trump may rattle the cage on these trade fights, but will not do anything to harm the
economy/cause a real market sell-off before the 2020 election. The admission by Chairman Powell yesterday that trade-related developments will impact Federal Reserve monetary policy decisions will only serve to reinforce the belief that there is both a Trump and Fed put on the market. We acknowledge this dynamic, but continue to believe that there consistently has been too much optimism for a resolution/real risk of escalation.

Soundbuy Ja....
11:16 am
BE11:17am

It's never not going to surprise me intelligent people have to analyse Emperor Incitatus like is actions have some reason.

nightingale20201 After Wed, FED is a lame duck now, Trump can do whatever he wants with rates at least in the near term
BE11:17am

Back to Commerzbank, in English this time.

BE11:18am

FX specific.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

"Madness has no purpose, or reason, but it may have a goal” Mr Spock taught us. That is probably how we have to judge yesterday’s tweets by US President Donald Trump announcing 10% tariffs on the remaining USD 300bn worth of imports from China to be implemented as off 1st September in the process of the next round of trade negotiations. The fact that Trump nonetheless says the US “look forward to continuing our positive dialogue with China on a comprehensive Trade Deal” is unable to prevent a significant risk-off reaction. Of course the traditional safe currency havens yen and franc are able to benefit in particular.

BE11:19am

It seems clear what Trump is trying to achieve with this kind of escalation: Trump wants to turn the thumb screws and prevent China from protracting the trade negotiations. By doing so he clearly accepts additional risks for the US economy. The new tariffs, if they are imposed, will mainly affect final goods and will therefore affect US consumers immediately, which is likely to put pressure on private consumption. The latter has so far been an important contributing factor to the continued strong US economic growth.

CS1 @BE: Trump a horse? :-)
BE11:19am

By doing so Trump also put pressure on the Fed, either intentionally or not. The Fed had after all also justified its “pre-emptive rate cut" on Wednesday with the downside risks resulting from the simmering trade conflict. And by doing so had left it open how many rate cuts will be required to safeguard the current positive growth momentum. Following the renewed escalation in the trade conflict market participants expect more rate cuts and have ended the correction of their Fed expectations for now.

rise2010 This trade war is as tiring as Brexit
11:19 am
BE11:19am

The more the Fed lowers its interest rates though the more difficult it will become for the ECB to counterbalance this expansionary effect with the limited resources still available to it. As a result we feel more inclined to stick to our forecast of higher EUR-USD levels.

A. M. @CS1: or part thereof?
BE11:19am

How things progress for the US and the US dollar will depend now much more on whether there are signs that the trade conflict is increasingly leaving a mark on the US economy. We had a first taste of that yesterday when the disappointing ISM manufacturing index took the wind out of the dollar’s sails. Hence, the dollar might display similarly strong reactions to surprises with the labour market report today or order intake later. And there we were thinking that following the Fed meeting things might calm down on the foreign exchange market before focus returns on the Fed’s next step. No such luck.

All of us Every single German government bond now yields below 0
BE11:20am

Talfahrt. Alles ist talfahrt.

urgeview Unglaublich

undefined

Meanwhile, back on Planet RNS ......

chad_john Morning. Anything further on Goals Soccer Centres please? Quite an RNS this morning
chad_john @TEd fan snap.
BE11:24am

Let's start off with the relative good news.

BE11:24am

(@TED: it's dead, ted.)

11:24 am
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 429.10, up 15.6 (+3.77%), High: 433.00, Low: 418.40, Volume: 4.64m
BE11:25am

Q2 beats, pricing surprisingly positive ......

BE11:25am

.... and more importantly, no warning. Yet.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Guidance unchanged, unlike Lufthansa etc. So, bounce.

BE11:26am

Credit Suisse incoming.

BE11:26am

2Q EBIT 5% ahead due to healthy pricing, cost control and potentially
other revenue strength: IAG has reported 2Q19 EBIT of €960m, ahead of
CS at €939m and 5% ahead of company-provided consensus of €914m, as
unit revenue performance proved resilient and ex-fuel unit cost progress
impressed. Other revenue was up €107m (28%) to €487m, ahead of CS at
€437m albeit with comparable (undisclosed) costs likely attached, while
cargo revenue of €281m was modestly ahead of CS at €272m. Guidance
for FY19 has been held, when many market participants expected a
warning, and IAG’s earnings remain resilient in a volatile sector, passing on
2/3 of a c.€500m 1H fuel cost headwind despite demand challenges. BA
operating margins were down 1.2 points yoy to 11.8%, with bigger declines
at each other OpCo (1.7-3.8 points) driving IAG’s margin down two points to 9.1%.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Transatlantic and UK point of sale strong points in 2Q despite Brexit
concerns: Unit revenues were up 1.1% (CS 1.0%), which suggests flat ex-
Easter, with growth in every long haul market ex-LatAm. North Atlantic unit
revenues were up 2.9% (1.5% ASK growth), with APAC up 1.9% (6.9%
capacity growth). Europe was down 1.1% on capacity growth of 5.3%, while
LatAm unit revenues were down 11.5% on 15.3% capacity growth.
Impressively UK PoS was up 11%, as was the US, in 1H19. Unit fuel costs
were down 1.7% underlying at CC in 2Q, excluding related other revenues
(1H 1.9%). FX was an €8m positive for EBIT in 2Q.

BE11:26am

Holding guidance for FY19 illustrates resilience at a time when market
confidence is low: IAG continues to expect c.€3.5bn EBIT for 2019, which
compares to CS at €3,449m and company-provided consensus of €3,356m,
which we expect to be taken well (even if it does not assuage concerns over
Brexit and 2020). Unit revenues are guided flat at CC for FY, implying a
flattish 3Q/4Q, while ex-fuel unit costs are still guided down. Fuel bill
guidance has been moderated from €6.2bn to €6.1bn and capacity growth
has been trimmed from 5.3% to 5%, as management remains prudent given
macro uncertainty.

BE11:27am

And Morgan Stanley.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

We believe the flat YoY EBIT guidance was largely expected, but unit revenue performance is enough to support the unit CASK pressures in the quarter and we believe is sufficient to support consensus.

nightingale20201 @Irish...has the fundamental changed that much ..granted Chinese's & Turk's stake..their debt level or cashflow (unknown with summer bookings) has not changed a great deal...
BE11:27am

IAG reported adj. Op. income of €960m vs Cons median at €914mn (mean €906m) for 2Q19 and above vs MSe at €893m. 2Q19 RASK ex FX trends up 1.1% (versus 1Q19 exit rates of +1.4%). Total revenues of €6.771bn rose 9.5% in the 2Q19, driven primarily by volume growth and strong contributions from other revenue. Reported unit cost ex fuel performance saw a headwind up 1.6% and ex FX was up 0.4%. The company notes FX tailwind amounted to €8m at the EBIT level in the quarter.

BE11:27am

Solid cash generation meant a group net debt to EBITDA shrank from 1.2x to 0.9x versus year end 2018. FY19 capacity now expected to be 5.0% vs 5.3% previously.Guidance: At current fuel prices and exchange rates, IAG expects its 2019 operating profit before exceptional items to be in line with 2018 pro forma (€3,485m); Cons at €3,356mn. Passenger unit revenue is expected to be flat at constant currency and non-fuel unit cost is expected to improve at constant currency (this has been updated from FY18 where unit revenue was expected to "improve" and unit cost ex FX was expected to be flat). IAG note they expect passenger unit revenue at constant currency to improve for the remainder of the year. Consensus median for FY19 after including the impact of IFRS 16 is at €3,356m while MSe sits slightly below at €3,270m. Fuel guidance has been lowered marginally to €6.1bn for 2019 (vs prior €6.2bn), over an €800m headwind YoY, setting still a high bar to meet the flat EBIT guidance in our view. RASK ex FX by region - Europe -1.1% (vs -5.7% in 1Q19), Domestic +10.3% (+2.1% in 1Q19) mainly reflecting strong Spain domestic and North Atlantic +2.9% (vs -2.3% in 1Q19) with 1.5% ASK growth, were key positive drivers, while Latam -11.5% (vs -9.1% in 1Q19) due to weak macro economic environment particularly in Argentina and Brazil.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

So ... all is fine for now. And there are no major macro uncertainties on the horizon either globally or domestically so .....

BE11:29am

Kepler:

PBateman interesting from willie walsh this morning ''absolutely no demand drop seen as a result of brexit''
BE11:29am

Brexit is likely to imply economic consequences for both the UK and the
EU that are difficult to quantify at this stage; however, we expect UK GDP
to be more affected than EU GDP. Therefore, we believe the higher the
exposure to the UK, the higher the medium-term operating risk. Thanks to
their more flexible networks and cost structures, low-cost carriers have
historically outperformed during shocks. Of the companies we cover, we
expect a UK economic slowdown to most affect the operating performance of IAG, with EasyJet (Hold) and Ryanair (Reduce) also being impacted. We apply a 10% discount on the EV/EBITDAR 2019E multiple of 4x that we
apply to value Lufthansa, to account for Brexit-related uncertainties.

Irish Credit Company management said they are insolvent and need £750m of new liquidity to trade through winter. Changing the shareholders prior to a deal has no impact at all

11:39 am

chad_john And you have to ask where the NOMAD was in all of this, too.
BE11:41am

Whether it has any relevance in this particular case, I could not legally say.

undefined
Kiwi-juice Unibail please?
11:41 am
BE11:41am

RBS and BT on the requests list. Let's start with the latter.

chad_john Sports Direct's annual report's mentions of Goals from two weeks ago now reads very interestingly.
chad_john (from SPD): "We were assured by members of the board that the cause of the accounting irregularities was confined to one person. However, given the significant size of these irregularities and the timeframe over which they took place we need to understand whether the problem is wider than one individual acting alone. "
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 186.34, down 7.58 (-3.91%), High: 191.82, Low: 184.50, Volume: 11.87m
chad_john "We are particularly concerned that the second largest shareholder, Chris Mills, is also a non-executive director and thus has access to more information and insight than is available to Sports Direct as largest shareholder, this simply cannot be right in a matter so serious."
BE11:43am

Q1 headline beats, but it's low quality.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

All one-offs.

chad_john Make of that what you will I guess.
BE11:43am

Ignoring those you have Openreach doing okay and consumer doing badly.

BE11:44am

So ... trading retail customers for wholesale ones.

Punter Re RBS, numbers looked ok to me and doubtless the brokers are saying buy as they have for most of the banks for years but they have been dead money so far. I suppose one day they won't be and with Lloyds at least you get paid while you wait for the eventual reappraisal. But on Lloyds, I do wonder about residuals on their large car leasing biz, anybody any views on that ?
11:44 am
BE11:44am

Here's Barclays to summarise.

BE11:45am

The key bit of the BT earnings release is the c4% beat to consensus on EBITDA. Although impressive, most of this is in Openreach/Other, with Openreach showing strong uptake of VDSL services (albeit expected), and Other having a reversal of bonus accruals. Consumer was actually below expectations, with clear pressure on mobile ARPU (due to a number of regulatory impacts that we called out yesterday), and Fixed actually OK at flat. The FY outlook has been re-iterated. Key focus for the call will no doubt be (a) plans for accelerating FTTH build (was strong in 1Q), and (b) Consumer strategy (very topical given dynamic and competitive market and somewhat soft KPIs).

Viking1 New Ceo of RTN nice nil cost option schem ,
BE11:46am

Or if you prefer bullet points, Goldman.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Organic growth. We note BT reported -1.5% underlying revenue growth (vs.-0.8% 4Q19) and, despite the slowdown sequentially, strength in Openreach and lower quality eliminitations drove the beat. Underlying EBITDA growth improved sequentially at -1.1% (vs -9.7% last quarter).
Consumer. Consumer underlying revenue growth slowed -0.8% yoy (vs 2.6% in 4Q19) driven by heightened competition, and we note churn remains low and stable in the fixed market at 1.3% (vs last quarter 1.4%).
Enterprise. The Enterprise division delivered -4.5% revenue growth vs (-6.8% n4Q19).
Openreach. Overall fibre net adds trends slowed at +502k (vs. +693k 4Q19) and BT has now passed 27.6m premises with Superfast.
Global services. GS revenues were -5.4% (vs -2.3% in the prior quarter) and EBITDA growth accelerated at 17.6% (vs. 11.2% in 4Q19).
FY20 guidance. BT has reiterated all FY guidance including underlying revenue growth of -2%, EBITDA between £7.2-7.3bn and capex within the £3.7-3.9bn range.

BE11:47am

Gah. Formatting broke. Try Morgan Stanley off the conference call.

BE11:47am

BT's conference call was subdued. Management acknowledged that the business still faces significant uncertainties ahead. BT said they expect progress in the "foreseeable future", but we still see more questions than answers. 1. Fibre investments nearer, so a dividend cut approaching? BT were enthusiastic about the Government's ambition to roll out fibre to the entirety of the UK. BT want a Government-led switchover campaign from copper to fibre similar to the analogue to digital switch over in TV. BT indicated that they could roll out fibre faster than previously expected (mentioned a run rate in the past of 2.5-3mn pa). This will raise questions again on how this investment will be funded, which BT said could reach greater than £30bn (entire UK coverage). Management will consider increasing borrowings, reallocating capex and reducing the dividend, but did not say which they will favour. The prospect of a dividend cut (yielding 8%) will continue to weigh on the shares, in our view. 2. The consumer market is "significantly more competitive and aggressive than last year".

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Examples of offers in the market place include: (i) Fibre broadband prices reduced by £5-9/ month; (ii) Mobile tariff with unlimited data for £10/ month for first 6-months; (iii) Some operators saying they will price 5G at no premium. BT is in the process of relaunching new tariffs in the Autumn. Management were clear that their fixed line business will not be losing market share anymore. This could imply more price aggression from operators. 3. Towers - not looking towards monetisation: BT has no new message on towers despite the ongoing industry theme with Vodafone announcing last week the formation of a European towers company. BT said they would have to weigh up the potential for more competition and loss of network differentiation vs short term cash.

BE11:48am

And JPM's credit folks.

BE11:49am

We maintain our Underweight view today, having downgraded the
firm last week on fiber spending concerns and seeing today’s commentary as further affirmation. While we held a more positive view throughout 1H19 as we felt fears of an Openreach separation were overdone, we believe build pressures have increased notably of late (resulting from the UK’s full fiber aspirations and competitor rollouts) and do not anticipate a near-term dividend cut despite expectations for elevated capex and capped ratings for the foreseeable future. We expect UK risk to trade heavy on Brexit fears ahead of an October 31st deadline for the new administration, and with BT lacking CSPP 2.0 upside
potential we see EUR spreads offering little value versus non-eligible names AT&T and Telia. We expect 5yr CDS to remain wide of peers (+80bps bid this morning), and prefer a step-up in quality to Orange on the GBP cash front. We remain Neutral in USDs as we no longer see notable upside in spreads versus peers as levels have right sized since a December new issuance. Risks to our rating include tightening on a reduced fiber buildout plan, new UK government support for a rollout, or confidence in an alleviation of Brexit uncertainties.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Full fibre is a useful commitment for politicians to throw around, isn't it?

BE11:51am

Sounds like whizzy look-forward infrastructure investment for Britain 2.0 at a Treasury cost of approximately zero.

A. M. FTTH is a mini-stimulous to the roadwors industry, too.
CS1 Will 5G have an impact on fibre?
BE11:52am

Wouldn't want my divi yield be tied to PM Johnson's war-room election promises, personally.

A. M. CS1: I'd think that fibre-style datausage would not be possible with 5G (from a cost point of view)
11:53 am
BE11:53am

Meh, what do I know. Macquarie likes them.

BE11:53am

BT and in p rticular Openreach delivered a solid result in 1Q19/20 with a 4% beat to consensus. OIBDA at £1,958m compared to £1,892m, with Openreach delivering most of the upside. Openreach OIBDA was flat y/y as FTTc volumes outweighed the cuts in pricing, although FTTc additions of 439k were down on previous quarters and comparable with 1Q18/19. The results should help underwrite FY19/20 guidance and consensus estimates, and abate the
downgrade cycle

BE11:54am

Upside from more concrete plans. OP target 300p
 BT is suffering from a lack of concrete plans. Despite new CEO Jansen’s sixmonth
tenure (at a cost of over £1.5m), vagaries remain over the plans for
FTTp and the dividend. As we discussed in our note BT Group (BT/A LN) - A
fourth thing cannot be long hidden… fibre published on 12 June 2019, we
believe Openreach’s 15 FTTp “target is now a reality, as it’s politically
impossible for BT to now withdraw”. Recent political news flow on fibre
highlights the importance of the initiative.
 As such, we would welcome confirmation of the funding plans and we continue
to believe the dividend will be cut for FY19/20 to 10p. But this is implied by the
share price, in our view.
 A more concrete agenda should underwrite the valuation and improve visibility
– which is desperately lacking. This provides the upside to our target of 300p
and is the reason for our Outperform rating. We hope the new HQ planned for
Aldgate has more concrete plans than BT currently.

CS1 There's me thinking I could get rid of my landline with 5G.
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Why do consumers really need full-fibre?
11:56 am

BE11:59am

But against that underlying earnings missed consensus by 9% on lower income and management has essentially withdrawn the 2020 targets.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I used to design image compression silicon.
BE11:59am

These are absolutely not good results and a 12p unrepeating special doesn't sugar coat it.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Here's Cazenove.

BE12:00pm

The key positive from the RBS’s 2Q results is a higher than expected 12p special dividend which is 8p ahead of consensus and 4p ahead of our expectations. However, we expect the focus to be on the weak NII in the quarter which was 6.5% below company consensus (at £2.0bn) with a 6bp decline in NIM. This is driven by pressure from lower rates on the structural hedge and competition pressures which impacted NIM by 4bps. Although Costs came in 3% below consensus expectations, management has not increased the overall guidance for cost savings for the year which will lead to questions on the call about what more can be done on cost-take out. Management indicates that the group is unlikely to achieve the stated 2020 targets of RoTE greater than 12% and CIR

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @Shinshin Your point on freeing up spectrum is the best argument I’ve heard.
Burn that spreadsheet Second Prudential SVP

BE12:04pm

The 2Q19 conference call has just concluded, and we highlight the following key takeaways:
NIM: The group commented that it expects the NIM pressure to remain and be driven by (1) continued pressure on new mortgage pricing which is now at 80-100bp vs. back book at 160bp, (2) lower contribution from structural hedge as swap rates have fallen, and (3) higher costs related to MREL issuance (£3.7bn of new issuance in 1H19).
Pressure on mortgage pricing: The bank indicated that given the high level of liquidity in the market, it expects the pricing on new mortgages, currently at 80-100bp, to remain under pressure for at least the next 12-15 months. That said, as long as the rates stay above 80bp, the group is still making attractive returns (20% on current capital consumption and 15% post RWA increase).
ROTE: Although the bank moved its 12% ROTE target to medium term, it indicated that it would be disappointed if it fell short of the consensus ROTE forecast of 9.5% for 2020.
Ireland: The bank commented that it believes it will be possible to improve the profitability of its Irish business to meet is cost of capital, and take out capital from the entity on a 3-4 year view, and pointed out the lack of any better alternatives at this point. The group pointed out that it has been able to grow its share in mortgages.
Natwest Markets: The group reiterated its £1.4-1.6bn income guidance for 2019, however, commented that it is likely to be at the lower end of the range with 1H19 core income coming in at £0.7bn.

BE12:10pm

The rate is above the 12% we modelled and adds $56m of interest costs over the life of the bond, but the far more important impact as far as the shares are concerned is improved certainty around completion of stage 2 finance given the c.$7bn gap between the current share price and our NPV. Once the bond has been issued and the RCF terms finalised, the company will have fully financed project which we believe should sharply reduce the discount to our 68p NPV.

BE12:11pm

We model subsequent (lower risk bonds), which will be issued to offset draw downs on the $2.5bn RCF, at a 10% interest rate. Given the likely higher rate of the first bond, clearly risk on interest costs is to the upside. If we increase the anticipated interest cost on subsequent bond issues to 11.5% (also + 1.5% on our base case), then our modelled interest costs for the financing to 13mt would increase by $210m from $1.47bn to $1.68bn.

Its worth noting that this increased interest cost can be comfortably absorbed by available facilities. As each incremental $500m bond is issued, the available funds in the RCF only declines by $300m. As a result, the RCF provides an incremental $1bn of liquidity over and above the $524m (P60) contingency.

Plato the Cook @1st Lt.: High bandwidth comms can reduce need for transport and allow remote healthcare
BE12:11pm

In our opinion one of the major reasons for Sirius' discount to NPV (currently 80%) is financing risk. With completion of the high yield bond and the RCF (due before end-September), financing risk is largely eliminated.

Theoretically, we can break down the discount to NPV into three buckets and crudely ascribe weights to them, i.e; financing risk (30%), execution risk (40%) and market risk (30%). If we assume that delivery of the first high yield bond and the RCF removes 90% of the financing risk, then the value uplift from removing it should be in the realm of $2bn, implying a major upcoming re-rating for Sirius shares.
